NODE_TEXT:
# Measurement type

The measurement type depends on the operating mode selected. The operating mode can be selected for each channel. In safety mode the following measurement types are available:

- "2DMU" or "4DMU" for current measurements. (4 to 20mA)
- "Deactivated": The channel is not processed by the module.

# Measuring range

The selection options in the measuring range field vary depending on the selected mode (safety mode activated or deactivated) as well as the measurement type. If a channel is deactivated, it will not be possible to select a measuring range.

Note
If you are using Marshalled Termination Assemblies (MTAs), you should select 4DMU for the configuration, since the supply is provided via the MTAs.

Note
In safety mode, only the 4 to 20 mA measuring range is permitted. In this measuring range, a current of < 3.6 mA will produce a wire-break signal. If, however, the type of sensor you are using (e.g. a gas sensor) means that you do need to process signals that fall below this range, you can deactivate F wire-break detection. In this case, a current of < 1.18 mA will produce an underflow message.

For more information, please refer to the following FAQ: "How can process signals that are less than 4 mA be used with a 4 to 20 mA analog input module (F technology)?" (https://support.industry.siemens.com/cs/ww/en/view/23707365).

Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)
Operating Manual, 04/2018, A5E43228905-AA

# Configuring S7F/FH hardware

# 6.4 Setting system parameters for F-signal modules

# Discrepancy handling (analog inputs)

In the processing industry, no evaluation is generally performed between 2 signals on the module. 1oo1 is set for sensor evaluation. This makes all the signals available in the user program, where they can be linked in 1oo2 or 2oo3, depending on what is required. If 1oo2 evaluation is to be implemented on the module, you can find the parameter description for discrepancy handling in the online help.

Note

For details of possible types of interconnection, please refer to the FAQ titled "Wiring & Voting Architectures for ET 200M F-AIs".

https://support.industry.siemens.com/cs/ww/en/view/24690377

# 6.4.11 Assigning parameters for the SM336; F-AI 6 x 0/4...20mA HART

# Properties FAI6xISBit HART (R-/57)

|Parameters|Value|
|---|---|
|source_address|CPU 410-5H|
|target_address|1021|
|DIP switch setting|to 0) 11101|
|monitoring time (ms)|2500|
|Diagnostic interrupt| |
|Behavior after channel faults|Passivate the channel|
|HART_Gate| |
|Interference frequency SUP|50 Hz|
|Channel Evaluation of the sensors|evaluation|
|Channel Measuring range|20 mA|
|wire break detection| |
|Smoothing| |
|Channel Measuring range|20 mA|
|wire break detection| |

# Diagnostic interrupt

The diagnostic interrupt for the F signal module must always be activated in safety mode.

Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)

Operating Manual, 04/2018, A5E43228905-AA

# Configuring S7F/FH hardware

# 6.4 Setting system parameters for F-signal modules

# HART gate

This enables HART communication with the transducers to be controlled. ON/OFF switches HART communication on or off for the entire module, in a safety-related manner. If "Can be switched" is set here, HART communication may be enabled or disabled on the F-channel driver.

# Interference frequency suppression

Setting interference frequency suppression for the line frequency. The corresponding integration time of the analog digital converter is displayed. If you change this setting, the increment for the F-monitoring time and for the discrepancy times will also change automatically. The values set there will be adjusted to the next lowest value.

# Sensor evaluation

- 1oo1 evaluation: Each channel is considered individually and the input value forwarded to the CPU.
- 1oo2 evaluation: 2 channels are combined in all cases (0/3, 1/4, and 2/5). A discrepancy analysis is performed on the module and the configured input value is forwarded to the CPU.
Q: What measurement types are available in safety mode for current measurements?
A1: In safety mode, the available measurement types for current measurements are '2DMU' or '4DMU' (4 to 20mA).
A2: The options for current measurements in safety mode include '2DMU' and '4DMU', designed for 4 to 20mA ranges.
A3: For current measurements under safety mode, you can choose between '2DMU' and '4DMU' types, both supporting 4 to 20mA.
A4: Safety mode offers '2DMU' or '4DMU' as measurement types for currents, specifically for the 4 to 20mA range.
A5: When in safety mode, the module allows '2DMU' and '4DMU' measurement types, catering to 4 to 20mA current measurements.

# Configuring S7F/FH hardware

# 6.4 Setting system parameters for F-signal modules

# HART gate

This enables HART communication with the transducers to be controlled. ON/OFF switches HART communication on or off for the entire module, in a safety-related manner. If "Can be switched" is set here, HART communication may be enabled or disabled on the F-channel driver.

# Interference frequency suppression

Setting interference frequency suppression for the line frequency. The corresponding integration time of the analog digital converter is displayed. If you change this setting, the increment for the F-monitoring time and for the discrepancy times will also change automatically. The values set there will be adjusted to the next lowest value.

# Sensor evaluation

- 1oo1 evaluation: Each channel is considered individually and the input value forwarded to the CPU.
- 1oo2 evaluation: 2 channels are combined in all cases (0/3, 1/4, and 2/5). A discrepancy analysis is performed on the module and the configured input value is forwarded to the CPU.
Q: What happens if a channel is deactivated in the measuring range selection?
A1: If a channel is deactivated, selecting a measuring range for it becomes impossible.
A2: Deactivating a channel removes the option to choose a measuring range for that channel.
A3: A deactivated channel does not allow for any measuring range selection.
A4: The measuring range selection is unavailable for channels that have been deactivated.
A5: No measuring range can be selected for a channel once it has been deactivated.

A5: Configurations that include MTAs should opt for '4DMU', as the supply comes from the MTAs.

# 6.4 Setting system parameters for F-signal modules

# HART gate

Q: What current level produces a wire-break signal in safety mode?
A1: In safety mode, a current of < 3.6 mA will produce a wire-break signal.
A2: A wire-break signal is triggered by currents below 3.6 mA when in safety mode.
A3: The threshold for a wire-break signal in safety mode is set at currents less than 3.6 mA.
A4: Currents falling under 3.6 mA result in a wire-break signal under safety mode conditions.
A5: Safety mode configurations will issue a wire-break signal for any current detected below 3.6 mA.

# Configuring S7F/FH hardware

# 6.4 Setting system parameters for F-signal modules

# HART gate

This enables HART communication with the transducers to be controlled. ON/OFF switches HART communication on or off for the entire module, in a safety-related manner. If "Can be switched" is set here, HART communication may be enabled or disabled on the F-channel driver.

# Interference frequency suppression

Setting interference frequency suppression for the line frequency. The corresponding integration time of the analog digital converter is displayed. If you change this setting, the increment for the F-monitoring time and for the discrepancy times will also change automatically. The values set there will be adjusted to the next lowest value.

# Sensor evaluation

- 1oo1 evaluation: Each channel is considered individually and the input value forwarded to the CPU.
- 1oo2 evaluation: 2 channels are combined in all cases (0/3, 1/4, and 2/5). A discrepancy analysis is performed on the module and the configured input value is forwarded to the CPU.
Q: How can signals less than 4 mA be processed with a 4 to 20 mA analog input module in F technology?
A1: Signals less than 4 mA can be processed by deactivating F wire-break detection, allowing currents of < 1.18 mA to produce an underflow message instead.
A2: To process signals below 4 mA, disable F wire-break detection, which then recognizes currents under 1.18 mA as an underflow.
A3: Deactivating the F wire-break detection feature enables the module to handle signals less than 4 mA, with < 1.18 mA triggering an underflow message.
A4: For signals under 4 mA, turning off F wire-break detection allows the module to process them, with currents below 1.18 mA generating an underflow.
A5: Processing signals less than 4 mA requires the deactivation of F wire-break detection, setting the underflow threshold at < 1.18 mA.

# Configuring S7F/FH hardware

# 6.4 Setting system parameters for F-signal modules

# HART gate

This enables HART communication with the transducers to be controlled. ON/OFF switches HART communication on or off for the entire module, in a safety-related manner. If "Can be switched" is set here, HART communication may be enabled or disabled on the F-channel driver.

# Interference frequency suppression

Setting interference frequency suppression for the line frequency. The corresponding integration time of the analog digital converter is displayed. If you change this setting, the increment for the F-monitoring time and for the discrepancy times will also change automatically. The values set there will be adjusted to the next lowest value.

# Sensor evaluation

- 1oo1 evaluation: Each channel is considered individually and the input value forwarded to the CPU.
- 1oo2 evaluation: 2 channels are combined in all cases (0/3, 1/4, and 2/5). A discrepancy analysis is performed on the module and the configured input value is forwarded to the CPU.
Q: What is the default sensor evaluation setting in the processing industry for analog inputs?
A1: In the processing industry, 1oo1 is typically set for sensor evaluation, making all signals available in the user program for further linking.
A2: The standard sensor evaluation in the processing industry is 1oo1, allowing signals to be linked in the user program as needed.
A3: 1oo1 evaluation is the default for sensor evaluation in the processing industry, enabling signals to be utilized within the user program.
A4: For analog inputs, the processing industry usually employs 1oo1 sensor evaluation, facilitating signal availability in the user program.
A5: Sensor evaluation in the processing industry defaults to 1oo1, ensuring all signals are accessible in the user program for additional configurations.

# Configuring S7F/FH hardware

# 6.4 Setting system parameters for F-signal modules

# HART gate

This enables HART communication with the transducers to be controlled. ON/OFF switches HART communication on or off for the entire module, in a safety-related manner. If "Can be switched" is set here, HART communication may be enabled or disabled on the F-channel driver.

# Interference frequency suppression

Setting interference frequency suppression for the line frequency. The corresponding integration time of the analog digital converter is displayed. If you change this setting, the increment for the F-monitoring time and for the discrepancy times will also change automatically. The values set there will be adjusted to the next lowest value.

# Sensor evaluation

- 1oo1 evaluation: Each channel is considered individually and the input value forwarded to the CPU.
- 1oo2 evaluation: 2 channels are combined in all cases (0/3, 1/4, and 2/5). A discrepancy analysis is performed on the module and the configured input value is forwarded to the CPU.
Q: What must always be activated in safety mode for the F signal module?
A1: The diagnostic interrupt for the F signal module must always be activated in safety mode.
A2: In safety mode, activating the diagnostic interrupt on the F signal module is mandatory.
A3: Safety mode requires that the F signal module's diagnostic interrupt is always turned on.
A4: Ensuring the diagnostic interrupt is activated is a must for the F signal module when in safety mode.
A5: The F signal module's diagnostic interrupt needs to be enabled without exception in safety mode.

NODE_TEXT:
# Measurement type

The measurement type depends on the operating mode selected. The operating mode can be selected for each channel. In safety mode the following measurement types are available:

- "2DMU" or "4DMU" for current measurements. (4 to 20mA)
- "Deactivated": The channel is not processed by the module.

# Measuring range

The selection options in the measuring range field vary depending on the selected mode (safety mode activated or deactivated) as well as the measurement type. If a channel is deactivated, it will not be possible to select a measuring range.

Note
If you are using Marshalled Termination Assemblies (MTAs), you should select 4DMU for the configuration, since the supply is provided via the MTAs.

Note
In safety mode, only the 4 to 20 mA measuring range is permitted. In this measuring range, a current of < 3.6 mA will produce a wire-break signal. If, however, the type of sensor you are using (e.g. a gas sensor) means that you do need to process signals that fall below this range, you can deactivate F wire-break detection. In this case, a current of < 1.18 mA will produce an underflow message.

For more information, please refer to the following FAQ: "How can process signals that are less than 4 mA be used with a 4 to 20 mA analog input module (F technology)?" (https://support.industry.siemens.com/cs/ww/en/view/23707365).

Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)
Operating Manual, 04/2018, A5E43228905-AA

# Configuring S7F/FH hardware

# 6.4 Setting system parameters for F-signal modules

# Discrepancy handling (analog inputs)

In the processing industry, no evaluation is generally performed between 2 signals on the module. 1oo1 is set for sensor evaluation. This makes all the signals available in the user program, where they can be linked in 1oo2 or 2oo3, depending on what is required. If 1oo2 evaluation is to be implemented on the module, you can find the parameter description for discrepancy handling in the online help.

Note

For details of possible types of interconnection, please refer to the FAQ titled "Wiring & Voting Architectures for ET 200M F-AIs".

https://support.industry.siemens.com/cs/ww/en/view/24690377

Q: What does the HART gate control in the F-signal modules?
A1: The HART gate controls HART communication with the transducers, enabling it to be switched on or off for the entire module in a safety-related manner.
A2: HART communication with transducers is managed by the HART gate, allowing it to be enabled or disabled safely for the whole module.
A3: Controlling HART communication with transducers, the HART gate can safely turn it on or off for the module.
A4: The HART gate's function is to regulate HART communication with transducers, providing the ability to safely activate or deactivate it for the module.
A5: Enabling or disabling HART communication with transducers across the entire module is the role of the HART gate, done in a safety-related way.

# Configuring S7F/FH hardware

# 6.4 Setting system parameters for F-signal modules

# HART gate

This enables HART communication with the transducers to be controlled. ON/OFF switches HART communication on or off for the entire module, in a safety-related manner. If "Can be switched" is set here, HART communication may be enabled or disabled on the F-channel driver.

# Interference frequency suppression

Setting interference frequency suppression for the line frequency. The corresponding integration time of the analog digital converter is displayed. If you change this setting, the increment for the F-monitoring time and for the discrepancy times will also change automatically. The values set there will be adjusted to the next lowest value.

# Sensor evaluation

- 1oo1 evaluation: Each channel is considered individually and the input value forwarded to the CPU.
- 1oo2 evaluation: 2 channels are combined in all cases (0/3, 1/4, and 2/5). A discrepancy analysis is performed on the module and the configured input value is forwarded to the CPU.
Q: What is the effect of changing the interference frequency suppression setting?
A1: Changing the interference frequency suppression setting automatically adjusts the increment for the F-monitoring time and discrepancy times to the next lowest value.
A2: Adjusting the interference frequency suppression updates the F-monitoring and discrepancy times' increments to the nearest lower value automatically.
A3: The F-monitoring time and discrepancy times' increments are recalculated to the next lowest value upon modifying the interference frequency suppression.
A4: Modifications to interference frequency suppression lead to automatic recalibration of F-monitoring and discrepancy times' increments to the next lowest value.
A5: When interference frequency suppression is altered, it results in the automatic adjustment of F-monitoring and discrepancy times' increments downward.

# Configuring S7F/FH hardware

# 6.4 Setting system parameters for F-signal modules

# HART gate

This enables HART communication with the transducers to be controlled. ON/OFF switches HART communication on or off for the entire module, in a safety-related manner. If "Can be switched" is set here, HART communication may be enabled or disabled on the F-channel driver.

# Interference frequency suppression

Setting interference frequency suppression for the line frequency. The corresponding integration time of the analog digital converter is displayed. If you change this setting, the increment for the F-monitoring time and for the discrepancy times will also change automatically. The values set there will be adjusted to the next lowest value.

# Sensor evaluation

- 1oo1 evaluation: Each channel is considered individually and the input value forwarded to the CPU.
- 1oo2 evaluation: 2 channels are combined in all cases (0/3, 1/4, and 2/5). A discrepancy analysis is performed on the module and the configured input value is forwarded to the CPU.
Q: What are the options for sensor evaluation in the F-signal modules?
A1: The options for sensor evaluation include 1oo1 evaluation, where each channel is considered individually, and 1oo2 evaluation, where 2 channels are combined for discrepancy analysis.
A2: Sensor evaluation can be set to 1oo1, treating each channel separately, or 1oo2, combining two channels for analysis.
A3: Choices for sensor evaluation are 1oo1, with individual channel consideration, and 1oo2, involving combined channel analysis.
A4: In F-signal modules, sensor evaluation options are 1oo1 for single-channel assessment and 1oo2 for dual-channel discrepancy analysis.
A5: 1oo1 and 1oo2 evaluations are available, with the former assessing channels individually and the latter analyzing two channels together.
